article.title: Atmospheric Constraints on the Surface UV Environment of Mars at 3.9 Ga Relevant to Prebiotic Chemistry

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 1 illustrate about the optical properties of CO2 and H2O ice particles?
choices: They are strong absorbers across the entire UV spectrum.
They are pure scatterers for wavelengths between 195 nm and 500 nm for larger particle sizes.
Their optical properties are highly sensitive to particle size across all wavelengths.
They significantly absorb at wavelengths unshielded by CO2 (< 204 nm).

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the action spectra in Figure 2 represent?
choices: The relative impact of radiation on a given photoprocess as a function of wavelength.
The total amount of UV radiation reaching the Martian surface at different wavelengths.
The absorption spectra of different atmospheric gases present on early Mars.
The rate of formation of prebiotic molecules under different atmospheric conditions.

multiple_choice_question.text: What conclusion can be drawn about the surface radiance on Mars at 3.9 Ga based on Figure 3?
choices: It is highly sensitive to atmospheric and surface temperature.
It decreases rapidly with increasing atmospheric CO2 pressure.
It is insensitive to atmospheric and surface temperature.
It is significantly affected by water vapor absorption in the UV.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 4 indicate about the impact of temperature dependence of CO2 cross-sections on the surface radiance, even for very low CO2 pressures?
choices: It significantly alters the surface radiance.
It has a negligible effect on the surface radiance.
It causes the surface radiance to be highly sensitive to temperature.
It shifts the onset of CO2 absorption saturation to longer wavelengths.
